answers.author: Mike Cohen
answers.text:
Rachel, 
Many counties, cities, and towns across the US have been using Open Town Hall to get feedback from their communities via online surveys, polls, public comment forums, and ideation projects. In contrast to conventional online tools and social media, Open Town Hall incorporates many analytical and reporting tools so that you can glean a great deal of insight from the feedback. To learn more, go to  http://www.PeakDemocracy.com 
Mike

answers.text:
The City of North Port, FL is utilizing it's new YourNorthPort.com website. We have a survey online that residents can fill out, and we have a general "give us your ideas for future recreation activities" question that folks can respond to. In addition, we have printed surveys at each of our recreation centers. Check it out at: http://yournorthport.com/projects/recreation-opportunities. Hope this helps.

answers.author: Thomas Miller
answers.text:
National Research Center, Inc. (NRC) created PARCS™ to help Parks and Recreation managers understand what the public thinks about jurisdiction service mix and more. There is a lot there that managers find helpful and NRC’s survey experts help with other questions you might want to add, like those about services that are missing but desired. Alternatively, you can ask questions only of service users which requires a different sampling methodology and many different questions. Here’s a link to more information about the service http://www.n-r-c.com/services/PARCS.html

author: Rachel Leininger
text: I am looking for surveys that can be sent out to residents and Recreation customers to identify program needs that are going unmet.  We are looking to expand the programs offered (infant through senior) in various programming categories (special events, recreational, athletics) in order to better meet the needs of our residents.  If anyone has examples of surveys they have used to solicit such data, I would greatly appreciate you sharing.  Any and all suggestions are welcome!
title: Surveys for Needed Recreation Programs
